content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a colorful and enjoyable Clash of Code. It can be quickly solved.

It was fun to solve it. It took me around 11 minutes.

You should mention that there are no "?" on the edges, otherwise it will take longer than it was expected.

Why did you choose yellow for the fourth colour? For a more homogenous puzzle, it was better to include all the remaining colours (purple and orange).

Also, the spaces between colours added few good seconds to the resulting time.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash, plays with a very interesting and quite complex problem, but then simplifies it to the perfect level for a clash. Solved it in about 4 minutes using RegEx.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is an interesting clash of code, not too hard but not too easy either. I hope it will make some fun clashes !
Great job ! I really like this clash of code

Goal
* Please change "different color" to "different colors".

Cases
* The output of all visible tests is Y. Please revise them so that R, G, B, Y is the output in at least one visible test, which should be more useful for debugging purposes.

Thanks.

"Regions of different color" is grammatically correct. It emphasizes the aspect in which they differ, allowing for individual contrast, whereas "regions of different colors" would tend to refer to all such regions collectively.

I felt it better to spatially separate Y from X because the shape of the symbols is so similar, but I will use a different fourth color instead and implement your request. Edit: I've realized it would be better to use ? instead of X. Now resolved.

Thanks for the feedback. The spaces in particular I can't do much about, if the dimensions are to be clear in the stub code.

I'm using four colors because of the much deeper Four Color Theorem. These four seem to be the most primary, tho I'd probably choose much paler colors for a real map. I just wouldn't want to trip someone up with "Aqua" and "Beige" e.g.

Good tip, I'll add a note to constraints.

Lol yeah, I just found matches for /.\?+./ in the rows and columns (with spaces removed) and then used the characters found in those matches to deduce the only character that wasn't next to a '?'.

I'm one of those people who like to "have two problems" :P
